user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_bind:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_bind(struct linux_device *ldev,
			      struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	int result;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, ldrv->drv_name) == 0)
		return 0;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, SYSFS_UNKNOWN) != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO, "device %s in use by driver %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldev->sdev->driver_name);
		return -EBUSY;
	}

	attr = sysfs_get_device_attr(ldev->sdev, "driver_override");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s has no override\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldrv->drv_name,
				       strlen(ldrv->drv_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to set override on %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}
	ldev->override = attr;

	attr = sysfs_get_driver_attr(ldrv->sdrv, "bind");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "driver %s has no bind\n", ldrv->drv_name);
		return -ENOTSUP;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldev->dev_name,
				       strlen(ldev->dev_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to bind %s to %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "bound device %s to driver %s\n",
		  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The provided function uses only standard C constructs: standard function definition and parameter types, pointer dereferencing, string comparison (strcmp), integer and pointer returns, calls to external functions, and simple control flow (if/return). There are no occurrences of known compiler language extensions such as: nested functions, statement expressions ({ ... }) used as an expression, typeof, __attribute__ or __attribute__((...)), inline assembly (__asm__), labels-as-values (&&label), GCC builtins or __builtin_*, __extension__, GNU C statement expressions, or other vendor-specific keywords. Using macros/identifiers like SYSFS_UNKNOWN, METAL_LOG_*, and errno is normal and does not imply a language extension; the negation -errno is ordinary arithmetic on an integer macro. All declarations appear in standard form (no anonymous or unnamed parameters using extensions). Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions).
